lines.text: Nobody ever knows what it's like for somebody else. That's always the problem.
Hey! Don't go that way, you're gonna wal straight into the worst parts!
I don't care! I ain't scared of you or any other tough nigger that comes up!
[a long awkward silence]
Look, I didn't mean it like that.
Only one way to mean it.
Don't know why anybody'd eat unsalted butter. Might as well eat Vaseline. Got about as much flavor.
Being happy ain't nothin' more than havin' something to look forward to.
I used to play a little ball. I was small, but I made up for it by being slow.
I guess everyone is entitled to make a complete and utter fool of himself every now and then.
[last lines]

Now listen, this is not going to be like a Sunday picnic, I'm gonna tell you that right now. Ruby and my girls will be alright, I guess, but that nephew of mine makes your boy look like Mahatma Gandhi.
Whoa.
He might take a shot at you, or maybe both of us.

If he looks white it's 'cause his daddy's white. I don't know how he look, I can't see him like you can, and don't need to. I don't have the blessing of being able to separate people by lookin' at 'em any more.
I've never seen a damn Yankee yet that could operate more than a wheelbarrow.
When I look at you I see him. And I can't look at you anymore.
[begins laughing]
What's so funny?
How does it feel, Mr. Filcher?
How does what feel?
Being colored.
